Celeste.Action: Ignores off-camera request to look at the camera during family gathering.
Performs a clumsy square dance in front of family, capturing some attention.
Ignores off-camera requests to look at the camera, shows clumsy dancing at a young age.
Possesses a 'proverbial something' that occasionally captures attention despite not being conspicuously talented.
Initially appears lost and avoids eye contact, staring at her feet and not responding to a request to sing, indicating social withdrawal or discomfort.
Is described as kind and full of grace in her beginnings and writes her own lyrics, implying sincerity and personal investment.
Possesses a proverbial 'something' that captures attention; is a savvy businesswoman who writes her own lyrics; kind and full of grace early on.
Lost and staring at her feet, trying not to trip in stiff boots, not immediately acknowledging the off-camera voice.
Stands frozen in shock with blood on her face after Ms. Dwyer is shot.
Asks if Ms. Dwyer is still breathing, showing concern.
Pleading with the shooter to stop and offering to stand to comply and de-escalate the situation.
Remains frozen, mouth agape, does not move when instructed by the armed young man.
Questions whether the injured teacher is breathing, showing presence of mind despite distress.
Commands the shooter to stop and offers to stand, attempting to calm the situation despite obvious danger.
Plea to captor to let others go, offers to stay behind, and comforts a frightened girl.
Blinking a tear but maintaining composure to calm others.
Turns her back on Cullen and approaches others during crisis.
Attempts to negotiate with the gunman, offering to stay behind while allowing others to leave, showing presence of mind and self-sacrifice.
Keeps calm to comfort others during crisis, suggesting they pray together to maintain peace and soothe hysteria.
Turns her back on Cullen and approaches the group, indicating decisiveness in a tense moment.
Ultimately is shot and incapacitated before resolution, showing limits to her ability to control the situation.
Hums along faintly under oxygen mask, showing calm and a sense of resilience.
Apologizes to her mother for feeling sick, expressing consideration for others' feelings.
Stops abruptly during therapy and admits her discomfort honestly.
Takes pained steps on physical therapist's encouragement, demonstrating cooperation and trust.
Humms along underneath the oxygen mask despite her critical condition, showing calmness and resilience.
Acknowledges her symptoms clearly and communicates them to the physical therapist, demonstrating self-awareness and cooperation.
Stops walking to avoid worsening symptoms and requests to sit down, showing good judgment of her physical limits.
Feels nausea and spinning during rehabilitation but persists in attempting to walk with assistance, indicating determination but also physical vulnerability.
Cries, smiles, and laughs with Eleanor after emotional moment, showing vulnerability and connection.
Asks about her family members' whereabouts, indicating care and awareness of others.
Asks Eleanor to express sorrow on her behalf to the news people, showing concern for others affected by the tragedy.
Thanks her father politely and declines his offer to teach guitar, showing appreciation but also a boundary.
Plays a melody on her keyboard while comforting Eleanor who rests on her, indicating care and support.
Delegates speaking to the press by asking Eleanor to talk to them and gives clear instructions to express sorrow for the victims.
Chooses to try to sleep and clearly communicates her needs to her father despite physical discomfort.
Plays a melody on her keyboard trying to comfort Eleanor, but struggles to find the right note.
Sits quietly with reverence and closed eyes during a somber church service honoring victims.
Sits quietly and reverently with eyes closed during a solemn church service, reflecting composure and respect.
Performs a heartfelt and emotionally moving song in front of an audience despite physical difficulty and nervousness.
Acknowledges her sister Ellie’s help before performing.
Uses crutches to confidently approach the piano and perform a moving song despite physical difficulty and initial meekness.
Admits difficulty putting feelings into words and chooses to express herself through music instead.
Initial hesitation and meekness when starting the performance.
Acknowledges needing help with the vocal track and thanks the producer sincerely.
Politely corrects the session bassist and engages collaboratively about the music.
Stops singing when emotionally affected, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Asks manager to watch language around Eleanor because it bothers her.
Responds calmly and politely to manager's anxious pacing and instructions.
Assumes new confidence and collaborates constructively with the music producer.
Responds politely and professionally when asked about her background and injury.
Focuses intently on the discussion and asks about next steps.
Assumes new confidence in the recording studio and proactively asks to start the next track, indicating readiness and initiative.
Answers confidently about her dance background and carefully acknowledges her injury, showing honest self-assessment and professionalism.
Focuses and appears intuitively professional in the meeting, demonstrating awareness and engagement.
Responds calmly and graciously to the marketing PR’s cautious feedback about her music’s uncertain success by saying 'It’s fine. If it works, great, if not, that’s okay too.'
Expresses simple, polite approval of the proposed artwork by saying 'Yeah, it’s good, I like it.' despite THE MANAGER’s dismissive comment.
Does not engage in conflict or negativity when THE MANAGER acts petulant and critical towards the artwork and marketing PR.
Responds calmly and realistically to the marketing PR's uncertainty about her new tracks, accepting both success and failure with composure.
Expresses a clear and consistent opinion about the EP artwork, showing decisiveness despite manager’s differing opinion.
Acknowledges discouragement from another but remains hopeful.
Pushes through physical pain without complaint to continue working with choreographer.
Acknowledges the manager's warning but seems cautious about her hopes, indicating awareness and emotional intelligence.
Adjusts treadmill settings to a more challenging pace and keeps pushing herself physically.
Follows choreographer's instructions precisely, making repeated attempts to improve her performance despite pain.
Conceals her pain to continue working rather than taking a break.
Encourages herself by singing strongly and practicing diligently with choreographer, shows focus and effort.
Checks on family by asking Eleanor if she called their mom; expresses hope to return home often.
Perseveres through physical pain and immediately agrees to continue rehearsal, showing resilience and readiness.
Successfully executes new dance steps and adapts by incorporating singing while managing breath control as instructed.
Uses body movements to enhance vocal delivery when prompted, demonstrating adaptability and skill refinement.
Recognizes uncertainty about future success but maintains a grounded and pragmatic attitude about fame, indicating realistic self-assessment.
Shows some possible naivety or lack of assertiveness regarding possible big fame ('I don’t think that’s even happening'), which might reflect minor self-doubt or avoiding strategic planning.
Keeps her face straight trying to present her new look to Eleanor, hesitating to show vulnerability.
Responds with humor and light teasing to Eleanor's playful voice.
Asks if the news is bad, showing concern and openness.
Shows calm acceptance and gratitude towards the manager despite being overwhelmed.
Replies somewhat flatly or reserved to the manager about her excitement, indicating possible inward emotional conflict.
Tries to present a confident new look to Eleanor and remains composed when interacting with the manager.
Asks questions about how well the music is doing and listens carefully to the manager's update, showing engagement and awareness.
Expresses feeling overwhelmed despite good news, indicating some emotional vulnerability but maintains composure.
Shows uncertainty about ability to get into places, indicating some self-doubt.
Travels with Eleanor and manager to Sweden to work on music, showing commitment and collaboration.
Prays before bed with Eleanor, indicating sincerity and close bond.
Expresses surprise but accepts working with a top producer in Sweden and prepares to work on an album.
Engages fully in a rigorous, immersive recording process overseas, showing adaptability and professional dedication over seven weeks.
Felt alive, creative, and autonomous - in command of her own destiny.
Takes part in risky behaviors such as drinking with medication, riding speeding motorbikes, and casual sex with older boys.
Acknowledges feeling too sick to travel and communicates this to her sister.
Collapses after drinking and does not manage her health proactively.
Apologizes sincerely when confronted about a serious issue, acknowledges the problem without deflecting responsibility.
Shows surprise and quick reaction upon learning about urgent work task (making a video in LA within 13 hours), indicating attentiveness and readiness.
Agrees to terms (deal to stop manager’s yelling) calmly, attempting to de-escalate a tense situation.
Attempts friendly conversation with musician despite being caught off-guard and awkward.
Expresses insecurity about her music genre being pop and fears judgment.
Responds with mild teasing ('No you don’t!') to musician’s claim he loves pop music.
Points out her manager when musician asks to speak to someone, showing openness to social contact.
Manages a brief conversation despite being caught off-guard; answers questions clearly and directs the musician to her manager.
Is unable to smoothly advance the conversation, resulting in awkward silence.
Shows hesitation and embarrassment about her music genre, indicating insecurity.
Maintains honesty about her situation (not knowing if she is in the video, admitting to making pop music).
Fails to open hotel room door with her key when trying to enter, requiring external help or additional action.
Engages playfully and bashfully with Musician during choreography practice, creating a warm, human moment.
Shares a vulnerable conversation about trauma and the past with Musician, showing openness and introspection.
Refuses to perform a crawling drop move, playfully deflecting and making Musician do it instead.
Smiles and shares her recurring dream honestly with the musician, opening up emotionally.
Engages in an intimate moment with the musician, initiating physical closeness.
Expresses fear and vulnerability about being alone and unknown in her dream.
Weeps alone in the hotel hallway, showing emotional pain but isolated.
Engages in intimate conversation with the Musician, expressing complex emotions and vivid dreams clearly and thoughtfully.
Reveals vulnerability by sharing recurring dream and emotions, demonstrating self-awareness and emotional insight.
Fails to take action despite evident emotional distress as she wanders tearful and strung out in the hotel hallway early morning.
Urgently tries to wake Eleanor and the manager to turn on the news after hearing about the plane crash, showing concern for their awareness and safety.
Uses Eleanor’s key without explicit permission to enter her room, demonstrates intrusion and disregard for privacy.
Uses her sister's key to enter the hotel room and quickly tries to find the remote to turn on the news about a plane crash, showing urgency and presence of mind.
Attempts to wake up her sister and the manager, even though they are initially unresponsive, demonstrating persistence in a crisis.
Despite her emotional state (tears streaming), she is focused on gathering information and acting with purpose rather than panicking.
Lip syncing precisely on camera with a distinctive mask in a controlled performance, showing skill and confidence as a performer.
Continues a complex staged performance with backup dancers and multiple camera angles, indicating strong coordination and professionalism.
Does not manage to immediately get the remote and faces resistance from her sister, but keeps pushing, showing some struggle under pressure.
Responds to tragic news about a shooting with a focus on not canceling the show, minimizing the tragedy's emotional impact.
Willingly listens to the manager's explanation about the shooting despite her initial defensiveness.
Responds to tragic news about a shooting calmly and focuses on not canceling the show, indicating determination and prioritization.
Dismisses concerns about the shooting's impact on their show audience perception too quickly, potentially overlooking sensitivity or public relations consequences.
Expresses disbelief and desire to cancel the press to avoid distressing others.
Worries if Albertine is mad at her, indicating concern for others' feelings.
Proactively asks questions about the situation (masks/shooting), tries to understand the context to be prepared.
Suggests calling off the press to avoid dealing with the crisis immediately.
Expresses disbelief and frustration but then tries to think through options (press conference, calling off event).
Moves briskly and stays engaged with her team and surroundings despite the chaos.
Shows concern about personal relationships (asking if Albertine is mad at her) while managing crisis.
Expresses frustration and sarcasm about using tragedy as an 'opportunity'.
Is visibly strung out and distracted by surrounding chaos.
Questions the vague explanation about the coincidence, showing engagement with the situation.
Appears totally strung out and distracted amidst the crisis, indicating difficulty managing stress.
Expresses skepticism and sarcasm toward the manager's framing of the tragedy as an 'opportunity', displaying emotional resistance but lacking strategic communication.
Considers telling the reporters to 'go fuck themselves', reflecting emotional honesty but poor impulse control in a professional crisis.
Offers her daughter to come to her room and take a nap, reaches out in a warm embrace.
Acknowledges and empathizes with her daughter's feelings about not eating and feeling sick due to turbulence.
Expresses understanding by not blaming her daughter for not eating.
Appears anxious and uncomfortable, says 'I feel like I’m gonna throw up.'
Recognizes her physical discomfort but communicates it clearly ('I feel like I’m gonna throw up') and declines help appropriately ('No, it’s just my meds')
Spots Albertine off-screen and initiates contact, showing awareness and attentiveness to her daughter’s whereabouts
Offers comfort to her tired daughter by suggesting rest and embraces her warmly
Acknowledges the daughter's discomfort with food and turbulences, showing empathetic understanding
Fails to take charge with Albertine's hunger or nausea more decisively (simply accepting 'I'm really hungry' without proposing a concrete solution right away)
Invites Albertine for a solo girl's lunch, throwing a friendly arm around her while walking away together.
Tells the manager and Eleanor to relax and asserts independence for taking Albertine across the street without a babysitter.
Seems distracted or forgetful about the conference when asked.
Asks to take Albertine for a solo girl's lunch and negotiates timing with Eleanor and the Manager, asserting some control over the situation.
Expresses a desire to get out and clear her head, rejecting the Manager's offer for security and insisting she can handle the responsibility herself.
Seems distracted or forgetful about an upcoming conference, indicating possible disorganization or poor focus.
Teases Albertine to try and make her relax, then quickly waves and politely asks photographers to leave her alone.
Expresses frustration and irritation at the photographers' persistence.
Attempts to protect Albertine from public attention by wanting to leave through the back, showing consideration.
Reassures Albertine that she looks beautiful despite no make-up and offers to share hers.
Makes a self-deprecating joke about looking like a pterodactyl, lightening the mood.
Keeps personal, possibly hurtful information about others private to protect their dignity.
Expresses appreciation for face-to-face interaction without distractions like phones.
Suggests Albertine should listen to Ellie about taking away her phone, showing a protective or caring attitude.
Acknowledges being under stress, tries to keep a lid on her frustration despite blowing a gasket.
Clearly explains the challenges of the modern music industry and her need to adapt to maintain her career.
Expresses anger that family problems are being brought into her relationship with Albertine, showing defensiveness rather than constructive communication.
Fails to engage directly with Albertine’s concerns about Aunt Ellie, deflecting the conversation or showing an unwillingness to address underlying emotional issues.
Analyzes and critiques modern marketing tactics with clear insight and sarcasm, showing awareness of consumer behavior and business models.
Acknowledges that despite declining quality of her videos, her popularity and audience size grow, showing realistic understanding of her career trajectory.
Explains to Albertine the importance of having an 'angle' in life and industry, demonstrating strategic thinking and confidence in her approach.
Dismisses Aunt Ellie's abilities and choices in a condescending manner, asserting her own superiority and reinforcing her sense of responsibility and control.
Shows manic energy and attempts to force her perspective on Albertine, leading to a tense interaction and apparent communication breakdown.
Asks the bartender politely to turn off the music and orders drinks thoughtfully for herself and her kid.
Apologizes to Albertine for taking out her bad day on her and shows vulnerability by crying and admitting struggles.
Tries to reassure Albertine and force a smile despite emotional difficulty.
Politely asks the bartender to turn off the music, requests a drink and soda in a considerate manner.
Attempts to manage a delicate interpersonal situation by apologizing to Albertine and acknowledging her own bad mood.
Shows emotional vulnerability and breaks down crying in front of her child.
Expresses desire to personally tell Albertine about Dan, feeling hurt that gossip got ahead of her.
Shows vulnerability by trying to hide her tears when server brings drinks.
Tries to protect Albertine from harsh truths and soften the story of the breakup.
Dismisses the gossip by questioning Albertine’s sources and attempting to minimize damage.
Tries to manage her emotions and control the narrative about her breakup despite feeling upset.
Appears to withhold full truth and uses vague language to soften the impact of the breakup.
Feels that big moments are being stolen from her, indicating some insecurity or lack of control over her personal narrative.
Avoids eating and tries to hide her crying from the server, showing a controlled outward demeanor despite inner turmoil.
Responds indirectly and evasively regarding the breakup and possible infidelity, which could suggest avoidance or lack of openness.
Politely declines the restaurant manager's photo request initially, indicating desire to focus on her daughter.
Responds to persistent requests with defiance and anger, slamming hands on table and using profanity.
Expresses concern about being embarrassed in front of her daughter.
Gets physically aggressive by standing and getting in the manager’s face after being provoked.
Refuses to be passive and stands up assertively to the restaurant manager when feeling provoked and disrespected.
Allows emotions to escalate into aggression and profanity, causing a scene and risk of ejection from the restaurant.
Eventually considers her options and leaves the restaurant with her daughter, de-escalating the situation by exiting.
Turns and leaves the restaurant after confrontation, but shows protective behavior by wrapping arms around Albertine's shoulders and makes efforts to comfort her.
Calls the restaurant manager a 'prick' after being mistreated.
Apologizes sincerely to Albertine for losing her cool.
Insists on talking through the confrontation with Albertine to address the emotional impact instead of avoiding the issue.
Acknowledges Albertine’s feelings and encourages her to open up about her worries.
Minimizes Albertine’s worry about her and instead expresses concern for Albertine’s wellbeing.
Considers her options and exits the restaurant with Albertine instead of escalating confrontation.
Suggests an alternative route to avoid further conflict outside.
Acknowledges losing her cool and apologizes to Albertine.
Insists on discussing the incident with Albertine to process the situation.
Dismisses Albertine's concern for her and reverses it, emphasizing her own strength and responsibility for Albertine’s well-being.
Uses reassurance and physical comfort to soothe Albertine emotionally.
Calls the restaurant manager a 'prick' after leaving, which may escalate hostility unnecessarily.
Admits to ordering a glass of wine to relieve tension and reassures others she wasn’t drinking earlier, attempting honesty and to alleviate worry.
Drinks heavily and hides the severity of her problem, as implied by the narrator’s account of her binge drinking and resulting injuries.
Unable to maintain composure, slurs and stutters through a rant, pushes past Eleanor aggressively.
Is aware of Albertine’s situation and takes initiative by having her take a pregnancy test and confronting Eleanor.
Expects others (Eleanor) to act responsibly; shows some insight into parenting roles and consequences.
Harshly insults Eleanor with degrading language and calls her 'retarded' multiple times.
Physically presses fingers into Eleanor's skull in a threatening manner.
Threatens Eleanor with violence if her daughter returns harmed or infected.
Accuses Eleanor of mistreating her daughter and being a negative influence.
Despite harshness, shows deep concern for her daughter's wellbeing.
Confronts Eleanor directly about failures and expresses strong frustration, showing awareness of issues and holding others accountable.
Uses harsh insults and aggressive behavior toward Eleanor, which undermines effective communication and control.
Plans and commits to a press conference and round table events despite emotional conflict, indicating professionalism and responsibility.
Threatens Eleanor with extreme violence in an emotionally driven moment, showing impulsiveness and poor emotional regulation.
Decides to play the show despite uncertain circumstances, quoting her dad 'never postpone joy.'
Responds to attackers with a provocative, sarcastic statement comparing herself to a new faith and inviting terrorists to her show.
Admits to nervousness when confronted by her manager about her public statement.
Winks at Josie after being told to keep quiet around the press.
Deflects concerns about terrorists and a controversial joke by minimizing it.
Answers journalists politely and cooperatively during the press session despite being strung out.
Expresses refusal to give a statement initially to avoid giving attention to violent thugs, indicating a desire not to fuel negativity.
Acknowledges feeling sick about the casualties caused by the violent group, demonstrating empathy.
Smiles a bashful grin and openly talks about personal stress post-accident and the effort to bring the event to fruition, showing sincerity and humility.
Corrects the journalist about the severity of her accident in a precise but not defensive way, aiming to clarify rather than boast or deflect.
Clearly articulates her thoughts about nihilist radical groups, demonstrating lucid and precise language.
Acknowledges the complexity of her feelings about violence and casualties despite an initial dismissive attitude.
Explains the extensive preparation and consideration that went into upcoming performances, showing project planning and awareness of resources.
Corrects the characterization of her legal issues with careful distinction, implying awareness of public perception and facts.
Appears bashful or gives a grin when discussing stressful events, potentially showing vulnerability but not undermining competence.
Defends herself against the journalist's criticism by shifting focus to tragic events affecting innocent people.
Stops Albertine from rushing off and shows concern for her by expressing a hope that she didn’t take something, admitting she overreacted.
Pinches her daughter's side playfully and asks for forgiveness, expressing vulnerability about her daughter growing up.
Tells the manager to get his hands off Albertine, asserting protective behavior.
Writes a sincere apology note with flowers for Ellie and expresses love to Albertine.
Admits mental strain and asks the manager to stay with her, showing vulnerability and trust.
Suggests using drugs with the manager to cope and jokes about intimacy during the high, showing openness and affectionate camaraderie.
Jots down a brief apology note and takes initiative to make amends by sending flowers to Ellie.
Acknowledges her own lack of mental capacity and courage to confront a difficult situation regarding Joel Hedlund.
Recognizes when she is overthinking and decides to address her anxiety by consciously choosing to distract herself and reset mentally before the show.
Suggests doing drugs in the middle of a stressful situation (pre-show), which may undermine clear-headedness and professional decision-making.
Stops the car despite being late and insists on having a moment of silence to hold those suffering in their hearts.
Asks Albertine not to look upset and tells her to get a drink and take her seat, showing concern and calm reassurance.
Refuses to respond to the Laser Director's greeting, appearing detached or cold.
Corrects PA firmly when she is called 'Ms. Montgomery', showing defensiveness and lack of tolerance.
Assertively rejects use of her last name to the PA, establishing her identity and boundaries.
Asks about Albertine’s whereabouts and instructs her to get a drink and take her seat, indicating some level of situational awareness and management of her team.

Fails to engage appropriately with the Laser Director, ignoring or not responding to his introduction and questions, showing possible disengagement or lack of social or professional interaction skills.
Seems distracted and in poor physical shape, requiring assistance to exit the vehicle and being nearly dragged, indicating reduced personal capability or control.
Shakes everyone loose and braces herself against the doorframe, showing physical assertiveness and trying to assert control over the situation.
Shouts and rants belligerently, unable to effectively communicate her needs calmly, creating tension and conflict.
Expresses feelings of frustration openly, insisting on her personhood rather than being treated as an object, showing some emotional awareness and self-assertion.
Fails to follow requests calmly (e.g., to leave with Josie) and appears emotionally overwhelmed, diminishing her ability to act capably in the crisis.
Is overwhelmed emotionally, sobbing and dazed, unable to make sense during confrontation.
Expresses intense insecurity about her image and self-worth openly and repeatedly.
Attempts to communicate her feelings clearly despite emotional distress.
Cries openly, revealing vulnerability to her sister Eleanor.
Buries face in sister's neck, showing trust and seeking comfort.
Expresses concern for her fans and daughter, wanting to make the show amazing for her daughter.
Smiles and playfully interacts with her crew, joining their huddle and lunging playfully.
Playfully lunges at the crew like a prize-fighter, engaging enthusiastically with the group chant.
Leads the group chant with inclusive, uplifting phrases and high energy, promoting unity and excellence.
Uses confrontational language ('badd-est bitch in the room', 'bitches') when hyping the crowd.
Engages crowd with playful teasing and acknowledges shared pain, highlighting resilience and solidarity ('People have been trying to take me down for years but I won’t STAY DOWN').
Refers to audience as 'my little angels' repeatedly, establishing a friendly and inclusive tone.
Focuses performance on uplifting and connecting with her fans, emphasizing 'this is all for you.'
Uses grandiose self-reference and demands exaltation ('Exalt me all the way up past the stars').
Sings emotionally about being made of stone but feeling her heart begin to beat when looking at the audience.
Claims to have made a deal with the devil to survive, returning with a mission to bring great change.
Performs confidently on stage, successfully integrating complex choreography with vocal changes and commanding the crowd's participation.
Shares a cryptic and intense personal story about making a deal with the devil to survive and bring change, showing emotional depth but possibly uncertainty.
Maintains composure and acknowledges her exhausted yet accomplished state after a significant achievement.
